episode.title: Free Enterprise Fund v. Public Company Oversight Board

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We will hear argument first this morning in Case 08-861, Free Enterprise Fund and Beckstead and Watts v. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.
Mr. Carvin.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The board is unique among Federal regulatory agencies in that the President can neither appoint nor remove its members, nor does he have any ability to designate the chairman or review the work product, so he is stripped of the traditional means of control that he has over the traditional independent agencies.
On the other side of the balancing test, Congress provided no reason for stripping him of these traditional means of control.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Why do you call it an independent regulatory agency?
I mean, Congress wanted it to be independent of the profession.
That much is clear.
It didn't want it to be independent of the SEC, so why are you characterizing it as an independent regulatory agency?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, by making it public, it made it free of the accounting profession.
So then the next question is: Why didn't they have the same relationship between this agency and the President that the FCC and SEC have?
And, in those instances, the President can appoint and remove the members.
Now, why didn't they do that here?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: There was--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --The SEC doesn't have another overseer.

I mean, the SEC is set up like the FCC, the other independent regulatory commissions, but this is a board that has a relationship with the SEC, where it can't do anything that doesn't have the SEC's approval.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --There is a buffer between the President and the board, and that's called the SEC, and the board can do many things without the approval of the SEC.
Most notably, it can conduct inspections and investigations.
There is no statutory--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It can't even issue a subpoena without the SEC's approval.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --It actually can collect information from anyone associated with the people they regulate, the auditing committees.
If it seeks to get a subpoena from someone outside -- if it seeks information from someone outside--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So the SEC really could stop anything?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --It cannot, for example, stop what happened to the Petitioners here.
There is no mechanism in the statute, in any way, shape, or form, for the SEC to stop an inspection or investigation as it is ongoing.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What happened to the Petitioners here?
I think, if you were challenging what happened to the Petitioners here, certainly it would be a question of how you would have to do that.
You ordinarily go through the internal proceedings.
But here you are bringing a facial challenge and you say, never mind any particular proceedings; the whole thing is no good.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: No, no, and I'm dealing with the inspections issue at large, not for -- for Petitioner or for anyone else, there is no mechanism -- no existing mechanism for the SEC, in any way, to say stop the investigation.
Equally important--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When you say SEC adopt a rule that would give the SEC authority to -- to stop it?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, it couldn't, and -- but I think the main point is, Your Honor, it hasn't, and since it hasn't, it doesn't have that authority now.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I'm--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: But I can tell you--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I'm not sure that's the main point.
I think the main -- the main point is whether the FCC could stop it -- the SEC could stop it if it wanted to.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes, and right now it cannot, and that's because--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Never mind "Right now, it cannot".
If it issued a rule that said you need our approval--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes, it cannot issue such a rule.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --It cannot issue such a rule?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well, the provision they point to, 7217(d)(1), says it can relieve the board of responsibility, but there is nothing in the statute that gives the SEC to conduct the board's statutory duties.
For example, it couldn't say, we will now collect the fees that are going to the board, we will now conduct the registration that's going to the board.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, why -- why isn't this simply relieving the board of responsibility, saying, you no longer have responsibility for -- for investigation and inspection in these areas?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: But that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They could do that, couldn't they?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, it can't.
But even if it could, my major point is it can't--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, let's talk about whether it can't or not.
Why can't it?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --All right.
If you turn to 39 and 40a of the board's appendix, at the back of the red brief, the board's brief, it walks you through the statutes we have been talking about.
And at the bottom of 39a, that's 7217(d)(1), and that's where it says it can relieve the board of responsibilities.
And I have two points on that.
One is there's nothing in here that gives the SEC the power to assume the responsibility.
It simply says the board need not comply with that obligation.
My second point is: This doesn't stop the board from doing something.
If I relieve my associate of the responsibility to give me a brief tomorrow, I haven't told him he can't do it.
If I want to impose a limitation on him, if I want to say stop, I have to enclose a limitation.
And if you will turn to the very next page--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Don't -- don't you think that's what it means, though, realistically?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --You know, Your Honor, I think that would be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When you no longer have responsibility to perform a government -- governmental act, you no longer have authority to perform it.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --If you viewed it in isolation, that would be an arguable principle.
But if you turn to the next page, 40a, you see a very specific provision in the statute that talks about how they can impose limitations on the board.
And this is when they want to censure -- impose limitations upon the activities, functions, and operations of the board.
And what do they need to do?
They have to have a hearing that the board has violated or is unable to comply with any provision of this Act or without reasonable justification or excuse.
So Congress has established very serious barriers to the SEC even limiting the board's responsibilities.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, they don't have to -- they can't issue a subpoena without the board's approval, I take it -- the commission's approval.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: They have very serious information-gathering powers totally distinct from the board.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Any -- any person who is a registered association or anyone who is associated with them has to provide documents, witness testimony, wholly apart from a subpoena, so anyone who is within the regulatory--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Or what?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Or they will suffer the sanctions that are listed in the statute.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And the commission can't change the sanctions?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well, not -- obviously the commission can review the sanctions.
But the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And it can't -- it can't pass a rule saying, we don't want you to do that?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, sanctions of course are done with order.
They get to review the sanctions after the board has done it.
I'm talk about the prosecutorial, investigative techniques--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So as far as -- if the company was ever certain it was right and that the Accounting Board was out of control, completely wrong, the company would just say: I'm not complying--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well -- but--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --fine, do what you want.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And then at that moment, the group that would decide whether they were right or the board was right would be the commission; is that right?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, I don't think there ever would be a dispute about whether or not they would have access to their documents and their testimony, because it's written right in the statute--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It says you don't -- you can get it even without a subpoena?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes, absolutely.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Where does it say that?
Or I'll take your word for it.
I'll look it up.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What happens--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I don't want to delay you, so forget it.
I'll look it up later.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --What happens to the information that the board obtains?
Can the board go public with that--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: I think--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --or is it all confidential?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --I think there are certain confidentiality restrictions as part of their investigative and inspection thing.
It's -- it's the normal kind of inspection, where you go through the investigation and they would review the various documents.
And my -- but my basic point is that that is a very serious burden on American citizens.
That is something that is totally outside the SEC's control.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The -- the burden of time of compliance?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The burden is because it's difficult and expensive to comply?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: That would be one.
Number two -- and I think probably more important -- since the SEC doesn't review it, this board was created to make sure that there was no more Enrons.
So let's look at it from the other perspective.
Let's say the board was negligent or sloppy in ferreting out the kind of auditing standards and abuses that the statute was enacted to do.
The SEC would have no way of knowing that, no way of--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No -- but I'm -- I'm talking about the harm to your client and to the -- those similarly situated.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: There's the cost of compliance.
What other harms or dangers or risks are inherent in the power of the board unmonitored, unchecked by the SEC, to investigate?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: You're right, Your Honor.
The burden here is the burden that Mr. Olson suffered in Morrison v. Olson.
He was never indicted.
There was never any sanctions subject to review.
But he was subject to a burdensome investigation and that is the burden that affects American citizens that is beyond the review of the SEC.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But I've got one thing on my list.
I'm looking to what they control, can't control -- the commission.
And so far I've written that in your view the commission can investigate people without subpoenas, and the commission can do nothing about it, okay?
That's one.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, what's two?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well, I think that that is the main point.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.
So we only have one on our list.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --But I do want to emphasize that--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I'm not saying it's good or bad.
I just want to be sure I have a complete list.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --If I might elaborate slightly, Justice Breyer, I think it's important to understand that they have the ability to inspect foreign auditing firms, and the Cato Institute filed a brief that described the adverse reaction of the 27 countries where they are currently exercising this inspection power abroad.
That is totally beyond the control of the President, obviously, as well as the SEC, to say how these -- how these inspections and investigations are going.
The--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: They can't pass rules?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Again, they can pass rules, but the Attorney General--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: What -- what is the difference between what you are talking about and an employer who says: Look, I can't stick my nose in every bit of business that goes on in my office because that's impossible; otherwise I'd be doing all the work and I just humanly can't.
I'm delegating to you the responsibility to do X, Y, and Z according to these rules of conduct.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --There are three fundamental differences, Justice--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: What's the difference between that and this scheme?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --In your hypothetical, the principal has exactly the same powers as the subordinate.
Here the subordinate has statutory duties and responsibilities totally distinct from what the SEC can do.
In addition to inspections, they can--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Well -- let's break down each part of your argument, please.
You are suggesting that Congress doesn't have the power to determine that a particular principal or agent of the government doesn't have certain responsibilities?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, obviously they do.

And what I'm -- you were asking for -- I'm now trying to describe the relationship between the SEC and the board, and the one difference between the normal employer -- employee relationship is that the board has statutory authority wholly distinct from the principal.
Number two, if that subordinate didn't do things the way the principal wanted in the employment situation, the principal could fire the subordinate.
When can the SEC fire the board in these circumstances?
Only when they have committed gross abuses and after notice and opportunity for a hearing.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And if you have a statute that says each Department -- Commerce, Justice -- the Attorney General of the United States or the secretary shall appoint an inspector general who will in fact inspect and find ethics violations and that office -- he cannot be removed from that office without cause.
In your view, that's all -- and it would be unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: No, no.
In the Interior Department, those are of course the President's alter egos--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.
Well, why?
What's the difference?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, two differences.
One is the -- the Secretary of the Interior is the President's alter ego, and so, therefore, the President--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So you are saying that the -- the chairman of the SEC does not under the Constitution have the authority or the SEC does not have the authority to appoint individuals who cannot be removed without cause?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, I think there is two points.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Or -- or you might be saying they do not have the authority to appoint inferior officers of the United States.
I don't know why they wouldn't have that authority if the Secretary of the Interior has that authority.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well, because Freytag made it clear that there's a difference between an independent agency, like the Tax Court.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What's an independent agency?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well, in that case was an independent agency in the Executive Branch--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, what is an independent agency?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --One that is not subject to the President's plenary control.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But why isn't -- so why aren't they subject to the President's plenary control?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Because of Humphrey's Executor and because of the removal provisions, which pose very serious removal restrictions on the President's ability to control the SEC.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: But you just--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: The SEC.
What -- what restrictions?
Because, interestingly enough, my law clerks have been unable to find any statutory provision that says that the President of the United States can remove an SEC commissioner only for cause.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: It is silent, and -- but it still--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's silent.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then, in other words--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't think the government will think it has achieved a great victory if it comes out of this with the proposition that the SEC is not an independent regulatory agency.
And I don't think the government is arguing that position.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --They have not taken that position.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --But that was not what I have asked.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: I know.
They haven't taken--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I know.
I'm not interested in that.
I'm interested in an answer to my question.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And the answer to my -- my question was--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: There is--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --is there anything in the law, as far as you know, any statute, that says that the President cannot remove a commissioner or the chairman of the SEC but for cause?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: The answer is there is something?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Where -- where is that?
Would you refer me to that citation?
Because we couldn't find it.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: It's -- they're given 5-year terms, so obviously if you have a term of 5 years, there is no removal provision.
Under this Court's precedent in Wiener, if there is a term, you need to look at the function of the agency.
There was no removal restriction in Wiener.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought that both sides--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: The Court--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --I thought that both sides agreed that there is no statute, everybody agrees to that.
But I thought that the government, just as your side, agreed that the President could dismiss an SEC commissioner for cause.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes, with -- pursuant -- yes, for cause, but--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Even though there's no statute that says anything either way.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --And the reason we--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: For cause would be short of the 5-year term.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --The reason we infer FTC, and under Wiener, you need to look at function of the agency to determine the President's removal authority, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: "For cause" doesn't mean for failure to obey the President's instructions, does it?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Not under Humphrey's Executor, which made it quite clear that the President had no--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's why it's called an independent regulatory agency, because it's not subject to presidential control.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I don't agree with that, but I mean, you do agree.
I thought an independent agency is a function of a number of different things: where it is on the chart, what people's customs have grown up to, expectations about it--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: And I will--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --what the President might expect he can do or not.
But all those things are not what I'd call hard law.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --It may not be hard law, but--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well but if it's not hard law, then I wonder.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I mean, that's why I asked the question.
It's not what I have the answer to.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, if Your Honor wants to infer at-will removal of the SEC, that would be effectively overruling Humphrey's Executor.
And if you want to make a--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why?
In Humphrey's Executor there was no provision that said--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --There was a provision, which we know, that said the President cannot remove an FTC commissioner but for cause.
Have I been wrong on that all those years?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, you've been entirely right, but Humphrey's Executor didn't focus on the removal provision.
It said that that removal provision was constitutional, and the reason it was constitutional was because you could make executive actors separate from the chief executive.
The SEC, like the FCC, has always been lumped in with the FTC in terms of that.
If this Court wants to say that -- that those people are subject to the President's plenary--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'd love to say that.
That would be wonderful.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --I'm not going to stand in your way, because that would obviously--
[Laughter]
That would obviously render the board unconstitutional.
I think the key point here--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It would render the board unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes, because--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If an executive appointee who is a superior officer of the United States appoints an inferior officer, which inferior officer can be removed only for cause -- I mean, my goodness -- I can -- there are lots of shapes and sizes.
I can't imagine what would be unconstitutional about that.
What?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, if the President called up the head of the SEC and said, I want you to seek sanctions against the chairman of Exxon, under the traditional understanding of Humphrey's Executor the SEC commissioner would not be beholden to follow the President's direction.
The same would be true if he called him up and said, fire the chairman of the PCAOB.

And if that is so, then the President has no ability to remove somebody exercising a very important executive function, and unless we are going to rewrite what has been generally understood as the independence of -- of independent agencies, then there is a fundamental difference between the President's ability to fire an inferior officer at the Justice Department and fire an inferior officer at the independent agency.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This is not an argument you have made anyway.
Can we go on to the arguments that you've made?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: And in terms of that basic argument, he cannot control, for example, the appointment of the board members, which he could with respect to officers over whom he exercises.
He can't tell the SEC whom to appoint to the board.
And in terms of the question that Justice Scalia asked earlier, I don't think it's a statutory principle that you pretend--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: --Is it unconstitutional for the President not to be able to appoint an inferior officer?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Not an inferior officer.
But, of course, these are principal officers for three reasons--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Assuming we don't accept your characterization of them?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Then I have two other arguments, Your Honor.
One is: The SEC cannot be a department under Freytag, because it is an independent agency indistinguishable from the Tax Court.
And -- and what the Freytag majority opinion said was, if you are unlike a cabinet department because you are not subject to political oversight, then--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I hope your case doesn't rest on Freytag.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --So do I.
I want to take an opportunity to focus on the real point of Freytag, which was made very eloquently in the Freytag dissenting opinion, which was--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And the brief.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: The Appointments Clause is designed to achieve accountability, and even when you are not talking about presidential advice and consent positions, the way we achieve that accountability is by vesting it, in the words of the dissenting opinion, in "the President's direct lieutenant".
And that's very important because it makes the President accountable for those positions, and it also makes them able to resist congressional encroachments.

And this scheme, besides, embodies precisely the evil that was condemned by every member of the Court in Freytag and in Edmond, which is it creates an unaccountable system where a multi-member commission beyond the President's political oversight and control is making appointments.
Not one elected representative, in the President or the Senate, has any influence who -- over the people appointed to this board--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Does that mean, Mr. Carvin, that the SEC cannot appoint heads of -- heads of its divisions?
I assume that they would fit within the characterization "inferior officers".

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --That would be true, and--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So -- but if the SEC can't appoint--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, they can't appoint inferior officers.
Now, the board with the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Yes, so what are -- so what are the heads of the various divisions of the SEC?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --The board and the SEC say they are not inferior officers, because they do not under Freytag have any specific statutory authorization.
They are not, in the words of the Appointments Clause, "established by law".
So if they are--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Aren't there -- aren't there people within the independent regulatory commissions that have jobs comparable to people who are in the departments--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --that the head of the department can appoint?
So who can appoint such people in the FEC, the FTC, the FCC, and so on?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: There are two differences.
One is, for those lower-level people within the executive departments, they have specific statutory creation of those offices, the Solicitor General on down.
There is no statute saying that anybody below the commission level at the SEC has any job.
That's totally up to the discretion of the commission.
They can vest them with whatever authority they want or not.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But -- but the question is -- I assume it's the follow-up question that Justice Ginsburg is interested in -- under your view of the case, why is that lawful?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: No, it would only be unlawful if they were inferior officers.
And if the board is correct that they are not inferior officers, there would be no constitutional problem at all with the SEC, for example, appointing a general counsel.
I should--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't understand that.
It's okay for them to appoint principal officers, but not inferior officers?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, no.
Employees, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh.
Oh, I see.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: And the argument for them being employees that the board has advanced is that they're -- that they're--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I wish you had said that.
You really had me scared there.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --If I am scaring you, I'm not doing my job--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're saying they are not inferior officers and also not principal officers, but merely employees?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Merely employees.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And who appoints -- who appoints the inferior officers at the -- at the SEC?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Well, that's my other point.
The chairman does, and so if you accept their view of who the head of the department is, which is the commission--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: All those appointments are presumably invalid.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --all those appointments are unconstitutional, so under their theory--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That would be a shame.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --since the chairman didn't appoint any -- the general counsel, the heads of any of the departments, all of them are unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Does the chairman serve as a chairman for a fixed term?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Not as chairman.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No?
Okay.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: He just has--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So, therefore, what you had said before would not apply to the chairman, that is to say: The President can remove him at will--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Not--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --There is no statute to the contrary; he does not serve for a fixed term, and so you cannot imply that.
Since the chairman cannot--

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --But this statute doesn't--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --can remove him at will -- you do not have what you would call the gearing into play, this somewhat mechanical jurisprudence, of what's an independent agency.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, he can remove the chairman at his pleasure, which -- but not a commissioner.
And that's our whole point.
That's a very key point.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So you are saying that the chairman, not the commissioner, is the person who does the appointing?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: We argue that.
They argue the opposite.
Under the statute--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --the commissioner does the appointing.
And that's our key point.

Because the President exercises such extraordinary control over the chairman and therefore is able to control the SEC staff, Congress, in the statute, took away that traditional enforcement mechanism.
All of the SEC staff you were referring to earlier, Justice -- Justice Ginsburg, are the chairman's alter egos.
And since they are the chairman's alter egos, they are completely constitutional.
And Congress, again, took away the chairman's powers, which was a way of limiting the President's ability to control the board.
And I think they -- but our basic observation--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So this whole thing would be constitutional if, instead of giving the appointing power to the commission, they had given it to the chairman?

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --No, because we believe they are principal officers for three reasons under Edmond: They run their own shop; the commission has no control over the officers on the board, since it can only remove them in these extraordinarily narrow situations; and as we have discussed at length before, it can only review part of its work product, whereas the appeals court judges in Edmond, all of their work product was subject to review.
And I think the removal provision is particularly important here.
The board can pursue policies that the SEC absolutely abhors and thinks are completely counterproductive, but under this extraordinarily narrow removal provision--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Isn't that a highly unlikely scenario?
I mean, this thing won't work unless these two are working in harmony.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: --Well, it would work perfectly if the board was an independent, autonomous entity that was not subject to the plenary control of the SEC, and that's exactly how the Senate report described it.

No, the New York Stock Exchange works perfectly fine even though the SEC has oversight responsibility over the New York Stock Exchange directly analogous to the oversight responsibility it has over the board.
And so, no, it would work perfectly fine if you followed the congressional scheme, which was an agency with its own autonomy and power.
And since it is an agency that has its own revenue sources, its own statutory authority, it has to be an agency composed of principal officers.
Elsewise very powerful agencies, including the CIA, for example, would be considered inferior officers simply because in an organizational chain they report to some others.

And I would argue, to get back to my original point, Justice Scalia, that that would absolutely confound the accountability that the Framers insisted upon, that either the President and the Senate or a direct lieutenant of the President make the kinds of appointments of inferior officers and that the important officers go through the advice and consent process.
If there are no further questions, I'd like to reserve the remainder of my time.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Carvin.

turn.speaker: michael_a_carvin
turn.label: Mr. Michael A. Carvin
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: General Kagan.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Resolution of this case follows from a simple syllogism, and it is this: The President has constitutionally sufficient control over the SEC; the SEC has comprehensive control over the Accounting Board; therefore, the President has constitutionally sufficient control over the Accounting Board.
Now, Mr. Carvin has suggested that there--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse me.
The President has adequate control over the SEC only because he can dismiss the chairman of the SEC.
But the activity here is not governed by the chairman of the SEC.
There's no role whatever for the chairmanship.
The -- the governance of this board is by the members of the SEC.
So that's quite different from saying -- you know, I -- I think your syllogism breaks down at that point.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, I -- I think not, Justice Scalia.
Humphrey's Executor said 70 years ago the President does have constitutionally sufficient control over the SEC generally, including the chair.
Now, the SEC has constitutionally -- has comprehensive control over the Accounting Board.
There is nothing that the Accounting--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The chairman, which is -- which is -- which is the -- what should I say -- the knife that the President has into the SEC, has no role in the control of this board.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --The -- the chair has the same role that he has with respect to pretty much everything else that the SEC does.
The SEC--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: No.
I thought the employees were appointed by the chairman, not by the commission.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Subject to the control -- subject to the approval of the commission.
So--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So you think -- you think a -- a veto power is the same as an original -- original power?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, in fact, the commission could do the exact same thing in this case.
The commission could delegate its control over the Accounting Board to the chair, subject to the control of the commission again.
So I think that there is no difference with respect to the SEC's supervision of the board than there is with respect to the SEC's supervision of any of its other functions or any--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, let's say--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --of its staff.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Let's say that the -- let's say that the board issues -- demands documents from a particular company.
Can the SEC direct them not to do that?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: The SEC has full control over the investigative and inspection function of the board.

This was what Mr. Carvin -- was the one thing that Mr. Carvin said the SEC lacked, but in fact it does not, because the board's investigations and the board's inspections are all done according to rule.
And the SEC in a number of ways can change those rules.
The SEC can reach out and abrogate any board rules, including rules relating to inspections and investigations.
The SEC also has power to promulgate its own rules, if--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse me, but, you know, Congress -- Congress can change the statutory authority of any agency just like that.
Does that mean that Congress is controlling the agency?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, it's certainly part of Congress's control mechanisms.
And this, too, is part of the SEC's control mechanisms with relation to the Accounting Board.
The Accounting Board can take no--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm not sure that -- that the ability to take away responsibility for an agency -- from an agency is the same as controlling what authority that agency does exercise.
It seems to me they are two different things.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --And I think that the SEC has both.
It certainly has the authority to take away responsibility from the Accounting Board.
The rescission provision in 7217 makes that completely clear.
But it also has authority to set the ground rules by which the Accounting Board does anything and everything.
It can say tomorrow -- it can promulgate a rule and say all inspections have to be approved by us, all investigations--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Will that be consistent -- do you think that will be consistent with the intent of Congress in establishing the PCAOB?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I -- I do think it would be consistent with the intent of Congress, Mr. Chief Justice, because the intent of Congress was to place the Accounting Board under the extremely close and comprehensive supervision of the SEC.
The references to independence that one finds throughout the legislative record here are almost all references to independence from the accounting industry, not from the SEC.
Quite to the contrary, Congress made it clear--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why did -- just out of -- I guess maybe it's not important, but why did the -- why did Congress set up a separate board if it's going to be entirely controlled by the SEC?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I think it is important, Mr. Chief Justice, and I think that there were a few reasons.
First, Congress wanted to make sure that this board did not compete with the SEC's own resources.

Members of Congress thought that the SEC had been resource-strapped and wanted to create something with its own separate funding stream, which it was able to do by declaring this a kind of quasi-governmental -- agency.
Second, it wanted to get the board outside of the normal civil service laws, because it wanted to attract people that it thought it could not attract on normal civil service salaries.

And third, I think history and tradition have a great role in -- in the question that you are answering, because what -- the history and tradition of SEC regulation of the financial industry in general is -- is -- in -- in some part through the SROs, the self-regulatory organizations.
So--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Before we get -- before you get too far into that, of those first two things, is there any reason Congress couldn't have achieved those same objectives by establishing the PCAOB as a division within the SEC?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, I -- I think so.

I think it would have been harder to establish a separate funding stream to take the Accounting Board out of the civil service when the rest of the SEC is subject to normal congressional appropriations and is subject to basic civil service laws regarding salary and so forth.
So, this was a way to -- to have both.
And it was also, I think--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But that's -- that's the history and tradition of this board, which isn't very long.
But the history and tradition of boards like this is that their investigative powers are independent.
Now, you say that there could be a rule, but that just isn't the way it works.
And if you refer us to history and tradition for other purposes, we ought to look at the operational principles, operational assumptions of this board.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, I -- I -- I do think, Justice Kennedy, that -- that the way this board is set up, the statutory scheme and structure, makes it clear that the SEC has comprehensive authority not just over the rulemaking, but over the investigative and inspection activities of the board; that no -- no sanction arising from an investigation can be issued except if the board agrees; that no inspection report can be issued except if the -- excuse me -- except if the SEC agrees.

And further, as I said before, that the SEC can reach further back into the process and say, not only do we have this kind of veto authority over any sanction that comes out of an investigation or over any report that comes out of an inspection, but we can also change the way those inspections and investigations are conducted in the first place.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Does it have consequences for public companies subject to the board if it refuses to turn over documents requested by this -- this board?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, for -- for -- for public companies for -- not for the accounting firms in general, but for their public company clients, any subpoena would have to come, as Justice Ginsburg rightly said--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I know, but presumably you only get a subpoena when people don't cooperate.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --That -- that's correct.
And -- and certainly public companies could cooperate, and certainly public companies have cooperated with the board--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And what happens if they don't?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I -- I think that the board would go to the -- to the SEC for a subpoena, ask the SEC for a subpoena, and the SEC would choose whether to grant that subpoena and whether to allow the kind of investigation that the board wants.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Are there any other -- are there any consequences from the company's refusal short of -- that would not require the board to get a subpoena?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Are there any other consequences for the public company?

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: In the absence of the subpoena, if nothing happens?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I -- I -- I believe that that's the case.
I believe that it's the choice of the public company whether to comply or not.
If the public company chooses not to comply, the board has to go to the SEC and to get a subpoena.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Is it -- does it have a consequence as a practical matter for the company if it doesn't comply with a request from this board?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, the board does not regulate the public companies themselves.
The board only regulates the accounting firms.
Now, the accounting firms do, as a condition of their registration, have to present any documents that the -- the -- the board wants.
And so the accounting companies have a real reason to comply with the board's requests.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So there are in fact collateral consequences that take place without any involvement by the SEC?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, I -- I -- I think again the SEC could change any of the rules that govern inspections, any of the rules that govern investigations.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So if you had a statute here that said, look, if you don't comply with the board's request for documents, your authorities will be suspended, and if that were the statute, you would say, well, that's okay, because the SEC can always change that rule.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I think that -- that the relationship between the SEC and the board has to be looked at as a whole.
And it's clear that the SEC has control over everything that the board does or could have control over everything the board does.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: General Kagan, I thought that -- the Chief asked a question, he posed a sanction, and I thought that any sanction the board wants to impose has to be approved by the SEC?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, that's exactly right.
Any sanction, any final inspection--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I'm sorry, I asked you whether there were any consequences from the failure of the company to turn over documents; and is your answer that there are no consequences whatever?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --There are no consequences with respect to the failure of public companies -- not the accounting firms, but public companies -- to turn over documents absent a subpoena, which the SEC needs to issue.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: As a practical matter, does the President have any ability to control what the board does?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I think, Justice Alito, the President has the exact same ability that the President has with respect to every other aspect of the SEC's operations.
So, the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, that's--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well, why is that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But that's not true.
He can remove -- he can remove the chairman of the SEC.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --And--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And he cannot -- he cannot remove the commissioners.
And it's the commissioners that govern the board, not the chairman.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, it's the commissioners that govern all aspects of the SEC's operations.
The chair only does what is delegated to him by the commission or -- either -- or through the reorganization plans.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, let me give you an example.
Suppose the President objects to the -- the very large salaries that the members of the board receive.
What are their salaries?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Excuse me.
They are over $500,000.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And they -- did they decide that themselves?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Subject to the review of the commission.
And the commission has been active in this area.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose the President reads about this and he says: This is outrageous; I want to change it.
How can he do that?
Remove--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, I think he does--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: --remove that -- remove the SEC commissioners unless they take action against the board?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I think he does everything that he would do with respect to any other SEC function, is that he or some member of his staff would call the chair or would call other commissioners and say: I have a problem with this.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Would you please change it?
Right?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Would you please change it -- and -- and--
[Laughter]
--and with respect to that, that's exactly what--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I could do that.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, that's Humphrey's Executor.
Humphrey's Executor does indeed say that the President can't order the SEC commissioners in the same way that he might be able to--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --That's a 70-year-old precedent.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Right.
That's Humphrey's Executor.
But you have to add to Humphrey's Executor Perkins and Morrison.
Humphrey's Executor says you can limit the President's removal power.
That doesn't get you down to the board.
You have to also say the principal officers -- there can be limits on their removal authority of the board members.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I -- I understand the temptation to say something like, well, we don't really much like Humphrey's Executor, but we are stuck with it, but not an inch further.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I didn't say anything bad about Humphrey's Executor.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: But -- but--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I did, I did.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --But this in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We did overrule it, by the way, in -- in Morrison, didn't we?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --But two points.
This in fact does not go an inch further, and it doesn't go an inch further because of the SEC's comprehensive control over the board, which makes the board function--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What is -- I'm sorry.
What is the removal authority of the SEC with respect to board officers?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --The removal authority of the SEC with respect to -- with respect to board officers is a for-cause removal limitation.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: All right.
So there is a limitation there.
For cause does not include failure to follow the policies of the President.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Let's assume that that's correct.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So you need to rely on Morrison to make the limitations on what the SEC can do with respect to the board constitutional.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I think--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And you need to rely on Humphrey's Executor to make the limitations on what the President can tell the SEC constitutional.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Mr. Chief Justice, removal is just a tool.
Removal is not the ultimate constitutional question.

The ultimate constitutional question is the level of presidential control, and the presidential control here is exactly the same with respect to the board's activities as it is with respect to the SEC staff's activities--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, no, no, because you have got an extra layer there.
Let's say, I mean, that you have to have two violations of the for-cause provision.
You have got to have -- you have to meet the requirement in two places.
When the SEC wants to remove the board member, they can only do that for cause.

And if they decide, well, there isn't cause, I'm not going to do it, then the President under your theory has to remove the SEC commissioners, all of them, not just -- not just the chairman, and he can only do that for cause.
So you have got "for cause" squared, and that's -- that's a significant limitation that Humphrey's Executor didn't recognize and Morrison didn't recognize.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --But that for-cause provision is surrounded by a panoply of other control mechanisms--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Which one are we talking about, the first one or the second one?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --The -- the for-cause provision on the board members is surrounded by a panoply of other control mechanisms which function as a complete substitute, which give the SEC--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, let's just talk -- a practical example.
The board says I want to get the documents of company X.
The SEC thinks they shouldn't do that.
Okay?
Can they remove them for that situation -- in that situation?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, they can pass a rule that says no, you can't get the -- the documents of company X, and then when the board members go ahead and try to get the documents of company X--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Can they say--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --they can remove them.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --you are fired?
Can they say, you are fired because we have control over what you do and we don't think you should do that?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I think that they effectively can.
They would have to do it by -- I think that the easiest, quickest, most legally secure way would be to -- to do it by -- by promulgating a rule that says you can't do this.
And then--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: The easiest way to do it is to pick up the phone, not by promulgating a rule.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I said the most legally secure way to do it would be to do it that way.
I think that the fact that they have that formal mechanism means that they could pick up the phone and accomplish the exact same thing, because--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Can the President pick up the phone and fire the SEC commissioners?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --The President can pick up the phone and fire the SEC commissioners for cause, however "cause" has been defined.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: He thinks -- he thinks they -- the board should be getting the documents from the other company, and the SEC thinks they can't.
So the SEC tells the board, don't go after that company, and because they do that the President fires the SEC.
Does that work under your theory?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: So now the SEC has given the board one order and the President doesn't like the order that the SEC has given to the board?

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Again, the President has the same level of control over the SEC as he has with respect to anything else.
That's just Humphrey's Executor.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I'm not worried if it's the same.
I'm worried if it's enough.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, but that's Humphrey's Executor.
Humphrey's Executor said it was enough.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Right.
And then--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: And the question is whether this goes any further.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --It goes further because you've got to rely on the SEC to get to the board.
So there you've got to rely on Perkins and Morrison.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: You always have to rely on the SEC to do anything, to supervise anybody in its field of operations, whether it's the SEC's own staff or whether it's the board members, who stand in essentially the same relationship to the SEC commissioners as the own SEC staff does.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well, do you dispute the proposition that the more layers of for-cause removal you add, the -- the less control the President has?
Suppose there were five layers.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Justice Alito, I think it all depends.
I mean, we are not saying that a double for-cause provision is always constitutional, just as we are not saying that a single for-cause provision is always constitutional.
The question is, in what context does that for-cause provision operate?

And where it operates in a context like this one, where it is surrounded by a panoply of alternative and -- and equally effective control mechanisms, it simply should not matter that there's another for-cause provision.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, what do -- what do you say in response to their formal argument that heads of departments are those people whom the President has at-will control over, like the Secretary of Defense, and Freytag is support for that.

And these aren't those people, so the SEC's members must be inferior officers, and the Constitution says nothing about and implicitly forbids inferior officers from appointing other inferior officers beneath them.
All right, that's a formal argument, but I got that out of their briefs, and I want to know what you respond to it.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, Justice Scalia, who doesn't much like Humphrey's Executor, nevertheless wrote a brilliant opinion in Freytag saying that in fact independent agencies were departments, and -- and -- and so that commissioners of the SEC would be principal officers, their appointees would be inferior officers, if -- if those appointees were subject to the direction and supervision of the principals in exactly the way Justice Scalia said was necessary in the Edmond case.
He is--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.
So I -- so we have to take the dissent there as opposed to taking the majority?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --No, no, no.
Freytag -- Freytag reserves the question--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --whether the independent agencies were departments for purposes of the Appointments Clause and, indeed, in reserving that question, suggested that they thought that the independent agencies, so-called, were a very different kind of creature than the small, specialized units such as the Tax Court.
So I think that the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I want to ask -- I want to ask one thing: You want us to imply or find -- or you want us to infer from the statute that there's a power in the President to remove SEC commissioners for cause?
You want us to find that that is implied in the statute?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Justice Kennedy, the conventional understanding, really, ever -- ever since Humphrey's Executor, is that SEC commissioners are subject to a for-cause removal provision.
And the government--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right.
What is -- what is the authority for us to find that there is an implication in the statute to remove just for cause?
There's -- wouldn't that be unique in our precedents?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --I think that -- if I understand the question correctly, I think that the -- the implication about--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I mean, if there is a removal power implied, why isn't it removal for all purposes?
How -- why can it be limited to just for cause?
What authority do we have to do that?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Well, I think that the understanding about the SEC commissioners is that the SEC commissioners were, essentially, the same as the FTC commissioners, which, under -- which, under Humphrey's, were removable only for cause, and as I believe--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: But that's because the statute required it.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: --Yes, but -- you're exactly right, and it's a -- it's a perplexity of this law, but for many, many decades, everybody has assumed that the SEC commissioners are subject to the same for-cause removal provision, and the government has not contested that in this case, nor has Mr. Carvin.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: General Kagan, the government argues here that the head of department is all of the commissioners.
Elsewhere, it is the chairman of the SEC who -- who appoints inferior officers.
Now, which is it?
Are all those appointments by the chairman invalid?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: No, they're not, because all those appointments are made subject to the approval of the commission.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that's something quite different.
He makes the appointments.
They can overturn it, but the appointment must be made by the head of the department, and the appointments are not made by the commissioners.
They are made by the chairman.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, I think practice in this regard has changed in different administrations, but if you look at the amicus brief that was filed by the former chairmen of the SEC, they make clear that in fact the commission has ultimate authority over each and every appointment.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: What do they have to say about the theory that the SEC commissioners can be removed by the President?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: I believe, Mr. Chief Justice, that nobody has contested that question.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And you are not contesting it?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: And we are not contesting the question that the SEC commissioners, themselves, are removed by the President for cause under, I would say, a very broad for-cause provision, in the way that Bowsher suggested, not something that's niggling and technical.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, General.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Ms. Elena Kagan
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Lamken.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The SEC has pervasive authority over every aspect of the board's operations.
Board rules and sanctions have no effect, except as the SEC allows, and can be changed by the SEC at any time.
Board inspections and investigations are subject to plenary SEC control.

Not only are they conducted under rules that the SEC must approve, but the SEC can threaten or actually rescind the board's enforcement authority any time it thinks that's appropriate in the public interest.
It controls the board's budget and salaries, and it can reassign matters to--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I thought -- so you disagree with General Kagan?
I thought she said one of the reasons for taking the board outside the SEC is that they'd have an independent funding stream.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --Independent of the congressional appropriations process, not independent of the SEC.
Section 7219 is clear as water that the SEC controls the board budget, and the SEC in fact has used that control to regulate down to the level of the board members' salaries.
In addition, the SEC can impose rules requiring getting -- requiring the board, for example, to get SEC pre-approval for particular steps or particular actions.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you know any other agency composed of inferior officers that has the power to acquire its own budget, as this board does, by simply assessing a tax upon the people that it regulates?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: In fact, this board doesn't have that power, because it can only do so as the SEC allows.
Here, as in all other contexts, it is the will of the SEC that controls--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The SEC can overturn it, but it's up to the board -- the board can do it.
Do you know of any parallel situation where there is a, supposedly, agency composed of inferior officers who have the power to tax the public unless it's overturned by somebody else?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --Well, there's a bunch of other similar entities, such as the SIPC and the like, that assess fees, and many of their officers are appointed by department heads, rather than the -- than the President.

And so, yes, I think that's actually not an uncommon feature, but the most -- but the most critical aspect of this is, here, as in every other context, it is the judgment and the decision of the SEC that controls.
The board can propose, but it's the SEC that decides.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the board can act, and the SEC can, I suppose, retroactively veto their actions, but the SEC doesn't propose what actions the board takes, actions that can have significant, devastating consequences for the regulated bodies.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: Well, precisely the opposite.
With respect to rules, the board's rules are ineffective--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I'm not talking about rules.
Agencies in the government do not act only in implementing a particular rule.
They have authority to regulate.
And the board here, for example, can tell a particular entity: You have to turn over these documents.
They don't have to have a rule that says, this company must turn over the documents.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --And the SEC staff can do precisely the same thing.
In fact, right now they can issue subpoenas without asking the commission for consent.
